awd_titl_txt: CRII: III: Adding Exploratory Statistical Analysis and Prediction Support to SPARQL
awd_abstract_narration:
Search engines use semantic annotations to provide search results, which remain well hidden behind the familiar search box interface. Beyond web search and recent technologies such as virtual assistants, semantically enriched data appear in a wide spectrum of application domains, including but not limited to, bioinformatics, neuroscience, health care, and social and psychological sciences. Access to semantic data, however, has been restricted to those intimately familiar with Semantic Web Technologies, standards, and protocols, data formats, and query languages. This project aims to substantially reduce the effort and expertise required to access and analyze semantically enriched data, and therefore increase the range of applications that can benefit from such data. Furthermore, this award will support the development of PhD and undergraduate students, and a graduate-level course on the statistical analysis of semantically enriched data at the State University of New York at Albany.

The technical aims of the project are divided into two thrusts. The first thrust will develop a general approach to support simple and intuitive, yet functional, visual semantic querying. In particular, algorithms will be devised to automatically construct semantic queries from keywords provided through a search-like interface. The second thrust will open up the statistical exploration, analysis, and predictive modeling of semantic data. Specifically, new primitives based on ideas from statistics and information theory will be incorporated directly into SPARQL, the query language for retrieving, and discovering relationships from semantic data. An ontology will be designed to support alternative statistical operations. Computational methods and algorithms for query answering in this setting will be developed. These research aims will be complemented by a comprehensive evaluation plan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Semantically enriched data appear in a wide spectrum of application domains, including but not limited to, bioinformatics, neuroscience, health care, and social and psychological sciences. Access to semantic data, however, has been restricted to those intimately familiar with Semantic Web Technologies, standards, and protocols, data formats, and query languages. The goal of this project was to reduce the effort and expertise required to access and analyze semantically enriched datasets, and therefore increase the range of applications that can benefit from such data. To achieve this goal, the project set forth to: (i) develop a general approach to support simple and intuitive, yet functional, visual semantic querying, (ii) design new primitives based on ideas from statistics and information theory and incorporate such primitives directly into SPARQL, the query language for retrieving, and discovering relationships from semantic data, and (iii) develop computational methods and algorithms for query answering. In addition, the project supported the training of both undergraduate and graduate students on Semantic Web Technologies, and the development of a new course at the University at Albany, State University of New York.The project enabled 1 undergraduate student, 3 MS students, and 2 PhD students in Computer science to be involved in research activities related to modeling and representing semantic data, querying and preparing such data for analysis in Python, and analyzing semantic data at scale using existing BigData analytic frameworks. A female doctoral student has succesfully defended her thesis and has graduated with a PhD in Computer Science. A new course on the foundations, technologies, and applications of Semantic Web technologies was offered for the first time in the history of the Univseristy at Albany. A large-scale knowledge graph comprising facts about recipes sourced from online sources has been made publicly findable, accessible, interoperable, and reusable, and its corresponding ontology has been made retrievable through an open and free, globally unique and eternally persistent identifier. Conference papers and journal articles have been published. A library to facilitate statistical exploration, analysis, and predictive modeling of semantic data using distributed cyberinfrastructure directly in Python has been developed, and is about to be released to the general public. Computational methods and algorithms for query answering in this setting have been developed. Other lines of research to be pursued by the PI in the future have been identified.
